attributes.title: blatant dehumanization and politician
attributes.description: This study tests if different types of dehumanization (mechanical and animalistic) predict people's support for politicians from different racial groups (i.e., Black and Asian) differently

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Participants will be asked to rate Black, Asian, White, Black-Asian biracials  (counterbalance with “Asian-Black” biracial wording), Muslims (the latter three are included as fillers and will be used for exploratory purposes and other studies) using an animalistic dehumanization scale, adapted from Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, and Cotterill (2015), and a mechanical dehumanization scale (which the author created and validated in previous studies as independent variables . The presentation of the two scales will be counterbalanced, and so is the order of presentation of the demographic groups.

analyses.value: To test the hypothesis, a linear regression model will be estimated. In particular, the animalistic dehumanization of the candidates’ race and the mechanical dehumanization of the candidates’ race (coded such that higher score means less similarity to human) will be used to predict candidate evaluation. Critically, a term for the condition variable (0=Asian; 1=Black), a term of its interaction with the animalistic dehumanization variable (Hypothesis 1), and a term for its interaction with the mechanical dehumanization variables (Hypothesis 2) will be entered in the model. The significance of these interaction terms will indicate support for the corresponding hypotheses.

dependent.value:
A scale averaged from the following two items:

We would like to get your feelings toward this politician. Please rate this politician using something we call the "feeling thermometer." Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward them. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward them and that you don't care too much for them. You would rate the group at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. There is no right or wrong answer.

How likely do you think you will vote for this politician? Rating of 0 means that there is a 0% of chance you will do so.  Rating of 100 mean that you there is a 100% of chance, and rating of 50% means that you there is a half chance you will vote for this politician.

conditions.value:
Participants are randomly assigned to read one of the two versions of the following scenario, and some aspects of it vary by condition (see below). 

Please imagining that the following hypothetical politician is running for the position of a mayor in the city of Lakeview.
  [profile picture is an Asian individual in Asian condition]    	   [profile picture is a Black individual in Black condition] 
Name: [in Asian condition] Qiming Zhao [in Black condition] Maurice Johnson
On his website, he indicates that his priority as a mayor will be
Promoting an environment for job growth
Working together to support public education 
Maintain a positive working relationship between the Mayor's Office and City Council and enhance cooperation with our regional partners and other local governments in our area.
Investment in Infrastructure: address the city's pressing infrastructure challenges by improving our city's roads, bridges and stormwater systems.

hypothesis.value: It is hypothesized that the animalistic dehumanization of Black is more predictive of evaluation of Black candidate than the animalistic dehumanization of Asian is predictive of evaluation of Asian candidate (Hypothesis 1). In contrast, it is hypothesized that the mechanical dehumanization of Asian is more predictive of evaluation of an Asian candidate than the mechanical dehumanization of Black is predictive of evaluation of Black candidate (Hypothesis 2).

attributes.title: The Role of Personality and Government Transparency in Response to COVID-19
attributes.description: This amends the original preregistration for The Role of Personality and Government Transparency in Response to COVID-19.

summary.value:
This amendment is being made after collecting data, but before viewing or analyzing data. We are adding a research question and clarifying changes made to our data collection procedures.

Added Research Questions:
How does country-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to country-level political and economic differences? 
The extent to which personality matters may vary based on country-specific factors (like GINI-index). How do individual differences in personality relate to responses differentially across countries?

Data collection procedures: 
Amazon Mechanical Turk did not have enough participants from non-US countries to collect data, so we switched to Qualtrics. Other than the platform through which we collected data, everything else about the protocol remained the same. The primary participants were individuals recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk from the USA and Qualtrics from the following countries: Australia, India, Argentina, Mexico, Nigeria, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and China. The survey was translated into Spanish for Argentina and Mexico, Arabic for Egypt and Saudi Arabia, and Mandarin for China.

Sample size:
We lowered our target sample size to 100 participants per country to adjust for pricing and the cost of translations.

Statistical models: 
To test Research Question 4, we will allow a random effect for the slope of outcomes on traits and examine whether this significantly varies at the country-level. In addition, we will test whether country-level variables (i.e., Gini index, etc) are associated with the estimates of these slopes.

attributes.title: Spatial navigation training-induced plasticity in the human fornix
attributes.description: Our knowledge of the role of the human fornix in spatial navigation is limited, with the effects of active navigation on this tract unknown. Whilst plasticity associated with cognitive training has been demonstrated previously, those examining white matter have reported changes in diffusion tensor MRI metrics, which are difficult to interpret. Here neuroplasticity will be examined following custom-designed spatial navigation training using ultra-strong gradient MRI and a pairing of metrics to examine fornix microstructural changes in detail. We hypothesise that the fornix subdivision connecting the posterior hippocampus, implicated in navigation, will demonstrate greater change than the anterior hippocampal subdivision. Further, training-induced changes will be larger in a myelin-sensitive metric than in an axon density metric. We present the first pre-registered longitudinal plasticity study with active controls and confirmatory hypotheses powered a priori, which will advance our understanding of neuroplasticity, the fornix in human cognition, and the neural underpinnings of human navigation.

q1.value: Spatial navigation training-induced plasticity in the human fornix

q2.value: Kristin Koller, Mia Winter, Maxime Chamberland, Mark Drakesmith, John Evans, Greg D Parker, Erika Raven, Suryanarayana Umesh Rudrapatna, Chantal Tax, Derek K Jones

q3.value: Our knowledge of the role of the human fornix in spatial navigation is limited, with the effects of active navigation on this tract unknown. Whilst plasticity associated with cognitive training has been demonstrated previously, those examining white matter have reported changes in diffusion tensor MRI metrics, which are difficult to interpret. Here neuroplasticity will be examined following custom-designed spatial navigation training using ultra-strong gradient MRI and a pairing of metrics to examine fornix microstructural changes in detail. We hypothesise that the fornix subdivision connecting the posterior hippocampus, implicated in navigation, will demonstrate greater change than the anterior hippocampal subdivision. Further, training-induced changes will be larger in a myelin-sensitive metric than in an axon density metric. We present the first pre-registered longitudinal plasticity study with active controls and confirmatory hypotheses powered a priori, which will advance our understanding of neuroplasticity, the fornix in human cognition, and the neural underpinnings of human navigation. See 'Abstract+Introduction-KK et al. 2020.pdf' for background to the study.

q4.value:
The current study will be a longitudinal study to test the neuroplasticity induced in the human fornix following training on a spatial navigation paradigm. The spatial navigation paradigm employed will involve four weeks of training, across two groups: (1) route learning (RL) where participants will learn incrementally longer routes according to their individual capabilities to navigate to a target within a virtual maze; and (2) free navigation  (FN) where participants will navigate to a target within a virtual maze taking any route they wish  (see Methods for full description of the paradigm). The study design will include the between groups variable training group  (RL versus FN) and within groups variables time (pre- versus post-training), pathway (anterior versus posterior fornix division) and white matter microstructure metric (myelin versus axon). Our primary hypotheses focus on the effects of training on microstructure. In support of our primary microstructural hypotheses, we present behavioural hypotheses to demonstrate the validity of our training paradigm and offer a positive control. 

Effects of spatial navigation training on fornix microstructure 

Based on the evidence for a role of the posterior hippocampal fornix division in spatial navigation, our main hypothesis is that spatial navigation training will induce an increase in an MRI-based microstructure metric predominantly sensitive to differences in myelin (see 'Planned primary statistical analyses' for detailed description of analyses) in the route learning  (RL) group. 

To support our chief hypothesis, we predict the following:

1)	RL will induce an increase in a predominantly myelin-sensitive metric (macromolecular proton fraction (MMPF)) within the RL group;
2)	RL will induce a greater increase in a predominantly myelin sensitive metric (MMPF) in the posterior compared to the anterior fornix division within the RL group; 
3)	RL will induce a greater increase in the MMPF in the posterior fornix division in the RL compared to the FN group; and
4)	RL will induce a greater increase in a metric predominantly sensitive to myelin (MMPF) compared  with a metric predominantly sensitive to axonal properties (the restricted signal fraction (RSF)) in the posterior fornix division in the RL group.

Effects of spatial navigation training on cognition 

In support of our primary hypotheses predicting the effects of spatial navigation training on fornix microstructure, we will additionally demonstrate the validity of our procedure by showing within group performance change during training in response to the different task demands in both groups. Further, we will demonstrate an effect of training group on behaviour using a baseline measure of navigation repeated after training in both groups (positive control).
 
5) the RL group will demonstrate a reduction in the number of different mazes completed over time due to increasing task demands;
6) the FN group will demonstrate an increase in the number of different mazes completed over time due to decreasing task demands;
7) The RL group will demonstrate improved cognitive performance on a baseline measure of navigation post training (positive control); and
8) The RL group will demonstrate greater improvement in cognitive performance on a baseline measure of navigation post training compared to the FN group (positive control).

See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study design will include two groups of equal numbers of participants: a route learning group (RL), and a free navigation Group (FN). Based on results from our repeatability experiment (see FullManuscript.pdf), we have chosen two metrics of interest to include in our primary analyses; one ‘axon’ metric thought to be predominantly sensitive to axon density  (restricted diffusion signal fraction) in which an increase is not predicted, and one ‘myelin’ metric predominantly sensitive to microstructural properties specific to myelin (macromolecular proton fraction, MMPF) in which a quantitative increase is indeed predicted.  Our design will test whether a microstructure metric predominantly sensitive to myelin, rather than to axonal morphometric properties, shows a more marked increase in the posterior, compared to the anterior, division of the fornix, after 4 weeks of spatial navigation training. MRI scans will be collected at two time points pre- and post-training. Therefore, our between-subjects variable will be Group (Route Learning /Free Navigation ) and within-subjects variables will include Time (pre-/post-training), Pathway (anterior/posterior hippocampal fornix division) and Metric (myelin/axon).

	Since multiple comparisons would require Bonferroni correction, thereby restricting the required significance alpha, we aim to include only one myelin-axon metric pair (i.e., MMPF versus RSF) for each statistical test in our primary analyses. Although we predict similar effects in the other combinations of myelin and axon metric pairs, we aim to include these metrics in exploratory analyses only. Please see 'Introduction', 'Planned statistical analyses, power estimation and required sample size' and 'Planned primary statistical analyses' in 'Spatial navigation training-induced plasticity in the human fornix - KK et al. 2020.pdf').

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to equally sized predetermined groups using www.sealedenvelope.com/simple-randomiser.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
Eight raw datasets have been collected so far for this project, although five of these are incomplete as acquisition was halted due to COVID-19.

This leaves just three longitudinal datasets, but at the time of submitting this registration only the raw data are available and none of the planned tractography or derived metrics have been analysed. Therefore, all researchers involved in this work will not be able to identify any patterns in the data and no summary statistics are available at this point.

question.value:
Participants

A sample of 64 right handed, fluent English-speaking, neurologically healthy males and females, aged 18-35, with normal or corrected to normal vision and hearing, will be recruited from Cardiff University’s staff, student and community panels. Screening for eligibility to participate will be conducted prior to study participation. The screening session will ensure compliance with inclusion/exclusion criteria which include safety eligibility to undergo MRI scanning, normal to mild range anxiety and depression, and at least average range (≥ 25th percentile) estimated intelligence, working memory, learning, and information processing capacity when compared to test norms (see ‘Pre-study screening’ for list of assessments). Additional inclusion criteria will include access to a PC/laptop with Windows or Ubuntu, with keyboard, audio and internet (browser Chrome or Firefox). The sample will be randomly allocated to two groups (route learning (RL)  and free navigation (FN) ). Participants will receive monetary compensation for participation and all participation will be contingent upon prior written informed consent provided by each participant. Ethical approval for this study has been granted by Cardiff University’s board of ethics. In the event of participant drop-out, we will continue to test until the sufficient sample size is achieved. The data collection phase of this study is anticipated to be 12 months in duration. Due to the COVID-19 global pandemic data collection will recommence when it is safe to do so.

Pre-study screening 

Pre-study screening will be administered to ensure that both groups are matched according to age, demographics, mood and cognitive ability. 
Participants will complete the following assessments during screening prior to participation; 
1) a demographics questionnaire (inclusive of yes/no disclosure of relevant medical history); and
2) a mood questionnaire (DASS: Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)) where participants within the ‘normal’ and ‘mild’ ranges, but not within the ‘moderate’ or ‘severe’ ranges, will be included to control for the impact of depression (ie. scores ≤ 13) and anxiety (ie. scores ≤  9) on cognitive functioning; and 
3) a cognitive screen inclusive of: verbal working memory (Digit Span Task, Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale IV,Wechsler, 2008), visual working memory (Symbol Span, Wechsler Memory Scale IV,Wechsler, 2009), verbal and visual learning, and information processing speed (BIRT Memory and Information Processing Battery, Coughlan, Oddy, & Crawford,2007) and estimate of intelligence  (Test of Premorbid Functioning (TOPF), Wechsler, 2011).

The cognitive screen will be based on standardised tests, thereby allowing for performance comparison with normative data, which in turn will allow us to include only participants who perform at least within the average range relative to their age-matched peers, to ensure relative homogeneity at baseline and successful achievement of expected training demands. Finally, an MRI safety questionnaire will be administered to screen for safety eligibility to undergo MRI scanning. The pre-screening session will last approximately 1 hour.

See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf' for full description.

q14.value: Predicted effect sizes were informed from a range of effect sizes reported in related studies in the literature (See ‘Planned Primary Statistical Analyses’  for effect sizes used for each individual statistical test). We used GLIMMPSE (Kreidler et al., 2013) and G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) to estimate the required sample size with a power of .95 and significance alpha of .05. Pearson correlations between time points, pathways (anterior and posterior fornix divisions) and metrics (restricted signal fraction and macromolecular proton fraction) were used as inputs in GLIMMPSE and G*Power to account for variability in correlation among repeated measures (see Table 2). In each instance, the lowest r coefficient among the two metrics (MMPF/RSF), fornix divisions and time points was used to ensure sufficient power for the lowest correlation among repeated measures. Effect sizes were converted (standardised) to Cohen’s d, therefore, the standard deviation was treated as 1, and effect sizes were treated as mean values representing change for each statistical test. See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.

question.value: The between-subjects manipulated variable in our design will be Training Group: 1. Route Learning and 2. Free Navigation. See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'

Within-subjects measured variables will be collected before and after 4 weeks of navigation training and will include:

Microstructure metrics: 1. one ‘axon’ metric thought to be predominantly sensitive to axon density  (restricted diffusion signal fraction) and 2. one ‘myelin’ metric predominantly sensitive to microstructural properties specific to myelin (macromolecular proton fraction, MMPF).

Virtual dissection of fornix division with tractography: 1. posterior, compared to 2. anterior, division of the fornix, after 4 weeks of spatial navigation training. See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.
Please see 'Planned primary statistical analyses' in 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.

q22.value: Data will be assessed for quality prior to analyses. Due to the stringent pre-study screening protocol that aims to exclude participants likely to score as outliers or ineligible to undergo MRI scanning (see ‘Pre-study screening in Methods), exclusion of data is expected to be the exception rather than the rule. However, in the unlikely event that data may need to be excluded, the following additional exclusion criteria will apply: 1) MRI artefacts in the fornix; 2) participant drop out (failure to complete at least 75% of the spatial navigation training); and 3) failure to complete post-training baseline maze learning task. Fornix reconstruction in a single hemisphere will be used for subsequent analyses in cases where reconstruction fails to be demonstrated in both hemispheres. Participants in whom fornix reconstructions fail in both hemispheres will be excluded.

q25.value: Please see 'Spatial navigation training-induced plasticity in the human fornix - KK et al. 2020.pdf' for full description of study.

The sample will be randomly allocated to two groups (route learning (RL)  and free navigation (FN) ). Participants will receive monetary compensation for participation and all participation will be contingent upon prior written informed consent provided by each participant. Ethical approval for this study has been granted by Cardiff University’s board of ethics. In the event of participant drop-out, we will continue to test until the sufficient sample size is achieved. The data collection phase of this study is anticipated to be 12 months in duration. Due to the COVID-19 global pandemic data collection will recommence when it is safe to do so.

Pre-study screening 

Pre-study screening will be administered to ensure that both groups are matched according to age, demographics, mood and cognitive ability. 
Participants will complete the following assessments during screening prior to participation; 
1) a demographics questionnaire (inclusive of yes/no disclosure of relevant medical history); and
2) a mood questionnaire (DASS: Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)) where participants within the ‘normal’ and ‘mild’ ranges, but not within the ‘moderate’ or ‘severe’ ranges, will be included to control for the impact of depression (ie. scores ≤ 13) and anxiety (ie. scores ≤  9) on cognitive functioning; and 
3) a cognitive screen inclusive of: verbal working memory (Digit Span Task, Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale IV,Wechsler, 2008), visual working memory (Symbol Span, Wechsler Memory Scale IV,Wechsler, 2009), verbal and visual learning, and information processing speed (BIRT Memory and Information Processing Battery, Coughlan, Oddy, & Crawford,2007) and estimate of intelligence  (Test of Premorbid Functioning (TOPF), Wechsler, 2011).

The cognitive screen will be based on standardised tests, thereby allowing for performance comparison with normative data, which in turn will allow us to include only participants who perform at least within the average range relative to their age-matched peers, to ensure relative homogeneity at baseline and successful achievement of expected training demands. Finally, an MRI safety questionnaire will be administered to screen for safety eligibility to undergo MRI scanning. The pre-screening session will last approximately 1 hour.

See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf' for full description.
registration_responses.q16.question: The between-subjects manipulated variable in our design will be Training Group: 1. Route Learning and 2. Free Navigation. See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'
registration_responses.q17.question:
Within-subjects measured variables will be collected before and after 4 weeks of navigation training and will include:

Microstructure metrics: 1. one ‘axon’ metric thought to be predominantly sensitive to axon density  (restricted diffusion signal fraction) and 2. one ‘myelin’ metric predominantly sensitive to microstructural properties specific to myelin (macromolecular proton fraction, MMPF).

Virtual dissection of fornix division with tractography: 1. posterior, compared to 2. anterior, division of the fornix, after 4 weeks of spatial navigation training. See 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.
registration_responses.q19.question: Please see 'Planned primary statistical analyses' in 'Method+Analyses-KK et al. 2020.pdf'.

attributes.title: COVID-19 Face Masks and Ideology
attributes.description: As the U.S. government works to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, messaging is important in getting individuals to comply with public health recommendations, especially as the response from the public seems to be polarized along partisan and ideological lines. Using a recent CDC recommendation of wearing facemasks, I use Regulatory Focus Theory to predict that conservatives will be more responsive to messages related to promotion, while liberals are more responsive to messages related to prevention.

attributes.title: Estimating the mental health impact of COVID19 on United States Populations
attributes.description: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to impact the incidence, prevalence and extent (intensity) of multiple mental disorders (e.g., Posttraumatic Stress Disorder) and symptoms thereof (e.g., depression, anxiety) in numerous people and populations (e.g., Healthcare workers, quarantined, newly unemployed). We will conduct a systematic review and meta-regression of estimates and predictors of the mental health impact of pandemics/epidemics/outbreaks occurring within the last twenty years (SARS, MERS, H1N1, Swine, Equine and Avian Flus, H1N1 and 2014 West African Ebola outbreak). We will apply the estimates obtained from the meta-regression to estimate and/or predict the incidence, prevalence, and or extent of the mental health impact of COVID-19 in United States populations.

q2.value: The prevalence incidence/extent of depression and related disorders, anxiety and related disorders and psychological distress and related in particular United States sub-populations (healthcare workers exposed to infected patients, infected patients, recovered patients, quarantined people) will be larger after the onset of COVID-19 (relative to pre-pandemic time periods).

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a meta-regression of estimates and predictor of mental health impacts of epidemics/pandemics/disease outbreaks occurring in the prior twenty years (since 2000). Estimates and predictors included in the meta-regression will be obtained from data included in individual empirical, quantitative studies of these impacts, and from meta-data about these studies (e.g., type of epidemic, quality of publication).  Estimates obtained from the meta-regression will then be used to forward project (prevalence, incidence, extent/intensity) rates in U.S. sub-populations through modeling and/or arithmetical calculation (e.g., estimate of incidence of post traumatic stress disorder among exposed healthcare workers in prior epidemics will be multiplied by upper and lower bound estimates of exposed healthcare workers in United States to obtain high and low projected estimates).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Only extraction of data from individual studies has begun. No processing of data or computation of any statistics has begun. Forward projection/calculation of estimates in US population, the primary goal of the study, has not begun.

question.value:
To obtain estimates of the mental health impact of epidemics/pandemics and disease outbreaks occurring in the prior 20 years, we will conduct a bibliometric review of articles returned via Google Scholar, PubMED, MEDLINE, PsychINFO, Scopus and Web of Science using key search terms listed below (Columns 1 & 2). We will check references of included studies and systematic review to identify additional relevant studies. 

We will obtain estimates of mental health impacts (listed in column 3) only from studies that meet the following criteria: (1) published in prior 20 years, (2) includes estimates obtained from study explicitly targeting populations, patients, and locations exposed to SARS, MERS, COVID, Ebola, H1N1, Equine, Avian or Swine flu, (3) includes estimate (incidence rate/prevalence rate/intensity mean) of one or more of the mental health impact listed in column 3, and size of sample from which estimate was obtained, (4) publication in English, (5) peer reviewed, (6) includes standardized measure of mental health impact with published psychometric data and reasonable evidence of reliability and validity, (7) includes clear description of methods used to assess and score standardized measurement instrument. 
 
Search Terms (we crossed words from Column 1 with words from Column 2 to form all possible combinations of terms):

1
Avian flu
Corona
Virus
COVID
Ebola
Flu
H1N1
Influenza
MERS
Quarantine
Swine
SARS
Respiratory

2
Anxiety
Depression 
Emotional distress
Mental health
Posttraumatic
Psychological distress

3 (Mental Health Impacts: Disorders & symptoms)
Adjustment disorder
Anxiety (all disorder/symptoms, including acute and posttraumatic stress)
Depression (all disorder/symptoms)
Substance use (all disorders/symptoms)
Psychological/emotional distress
Threat/worry (of pandemic/epidemic/outbreak) 
Burnout/emotional exhaustion
General/any (e.g., measured by SF-36 mental component scale)

q11.value: Sample size for the meta-regression will equal the total number of relevant estimates obtained from studies meeting the above criteria.

question.value: NA

Outcomes/Impacts

Adjustment disorder
Anxiety (all disorders/symptoms, including acute and posttraumatic stress)
Depression (all disorder/symptoms)
Substance use (all disorders/symptoms)
Psychological/emotional distress
Threat/worry (of pandemic/epidemic/outbreak) 
Burnout/emotional exhaustion
General/any (e.g., measured by SF-36 mental component scale)

Breakouts of estimates/sub-estimates (used as predictors)

Age
Gender
Income level
Education 
Job type
Exposure (to virus/disease)
Severity of infection
Severity of mental health impact

We will form indices of:
1) All-diagnosis/symptom & all-sub-population (oveall) rate (prevalence/incidence) estimates. Rate estimates are obtained from diagnostic instruments (e.g., Structured Clinical Interview for DSM) and from validated clinical cut-off scores for continuous measures (e.g. GAD-7) 
2) Rate (prevalence/incidence) estimates by diagnosis/symptom & sub-population
3) All-diagnosis/symptom & all-sub-population (overall) extent/intensity estimates. Extent/intensity estimates are obtained from continuous measures (e.g., SCL-90).   
4) Extent/intensity estimates by diagnosis/symptom & sub-population.

We plan to conduct a meta-regression including a random-effect summary effect (implemented by restricted maximum likelihood method). We will calculate a Q-statistic (to test for statistically significant heterogeneity between studies) and I2 statistic (to compute percentage of heterogeneity due to true between-study differences) using the
MAc (Del Re & Hoyt, 2010) and metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010) packages in R. Moderator analyses will be conducted with the meta-regression function (mareg) in R. We will assess for publication bias in two ways. First, we will examine a funnel plot for asymmetry. Second, we calculate the number of (a) composite estimates to include with a value of zero that would be needed for a null hypothesis (p > .05 for test of summary effect) to be retained, and (b) missing composite estimates that would be needed for every observed estimate for the overall effect to be nullified. 

Forward projecting of estimates in the U.S. population will occur through either or both (a) Markov chain modeling or (b) arithmetical calculations of estimates obtained through meta-regression and U.S. sub-population values (e.g., upper & lower values for U.S. healthcare workers exposed to COVID-19).

q19.value: Estimates of effect size will be used for all inferences.

q20.value: Only relevant estimates from studies meeting inclusion criteria will be included. Grey literature (unpublished research, non-peer-reviewed research, conference presentation) will be excluded.

q21.value: Incomplete or missing data will be excluded.

attributes.title: A Process-Based Online Intervention Study for Clinical Perfectionism

q1.value: A Process-Based Online Intervention Study for Clinical Perfectionism

q2.value: Clarissa W. Ong, Eric Lee, Michael Levin, Michael Twohig

q3.value: In clinical psychology, there has been a growing movement toward process-based therapy (PBT), which conceptualizes assessment and intervention based on shared principles and ideas across empirically supported approaches. The goal of PBT is to improve human wellbeing with evidence-based procedures and processes of change. While PBT has the potential to increase availability and accessibility of resources, more precise tests of its application are needed to clarify its real-world feasibility. The proposed project aims to test the feasibility of the PBT model using an online app intervention (containing two training modules) targeting clinical perfectionism. Clinical perfectionism was chosen because like PBT it is defined by processes (e.g., rigidity around personal standards) rather than specific behaviors or symptoms. It is also transdiagnostic in that perfectionism is relevant to many diagnoses including OCD, OCPD, GAD, and anorexia nervosa. The trainings will teach cognitive variation and motivational variation respectively, two elements of PBT. Cognitive variation refers to responding flexibly to cognitive stimuli (e.g., reappraisal, decentering) whereas motivational variation refers to being able to contact reinforcement for behaviors from various sources (e.g., tangible rewards, values). We hypothesize: (1) the trainings will specifically move the change processes they target (e.g., cognitive variation training will increase cognitive variation), showing precision of procedures, and (2) the change processes will, in turn, move meaningful outcomes, showing relevance of change processes to personal well-being. Support for these hypotheses would provide evidence that the PBT approach is feasible, effective, and can be applied with precision. Future research can build on this work and focus on refining intervention approaches in line with PBT principles to improve quality and accessibility of mental health services.

q4.value:
1.	Cognitive processes will significantly increase following CVT more so than motivational processes (test of procedural specificity).
2.	Motivational processes will significantly increase following MVT more so than cognitive processes (test of procedural specificity).
3.	Increases in cognitive processes will predict increases in well-being (test of process utility).
4.	Increases in motivational processes will predict increases in well-being (test of process utility).
5.	Both trainings will lead to bigger increases in processes and well-being than each training alone (test of incremental benefit).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The design is a randomized controlled crossover trial with two online trainings. We chose a crossover design because (1) participants serve as their own controls, minimizing the confounding influence of covariates, and (2) it allows investigation of each training, their combined effect, and potential order effects.

All components of the study will be delivered online, including gathering informed consent, completing the screening, intervention, and assessment at all time points. Individuals who are interested in participating in the study will provide informed consent and then be asked to complete a short screening. Those who qualify for the study will then complete a pre-intervention assessment battery and then be randomized to a starting intervention, either CVT or MVT. Participants will be prompted to complete two, 15–20 minute sessions each week. Combined, participants will complete eight sessions (four CVT and four MVT) over the course of four weeks. Assessment will be conducted at nine timepoints: baseline, twice during CVT and MVT interventions (four total), post CVT and MVT interventions (two total), and at three-month and six-month follow-up.

We will use multilevel models to investigate the effect of trainings on change processes (i.e., cognitive variation and motivational variation) and wellbeing over time (within-group effect).

q9.value: Block randomization will be used to produce groups of relatively equal sizes (Suresh, 2011). We selected a block size of eight to have greater control of group balance over time. In total, we randomized ten blocks of eight to account for participant dropout (target n = 50). We will use a random number table using https://stattrek.com/statistics/random-number-generator.aspx to create even blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited using online postings (e.g., Facebook, Reddit). To increase demographic diversity, we will primarily use “push out” strategies (i.e., target online users who are not primarily looking to participate in research) to advertise the study (Antoun, Zhang, Conrad, & Schober, 2016).

Inclusion criteria for the study include: (1) reliable Internet and smartphone access, (2) at least 18 years old, (3) score of ≥29 (one standard deviation above nonclinical mean) on the Concern Over Mistakes subscale on the Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (cut-off used in a previous telehealth treatment trial; Frost, Marten, Lahart, & Rosenblate, 1990; Rozental et al., 2017), and (4) fluency in English. Exclusion criteria include (1) self-reported suicidality and (2) concurrent psychotherapy.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 50 completers. The total sample size may be more than 50, including noncompleters. We will use an intent to treat analysis with the full sample.

q14.value: We used the simr (Green & MacLeod, 2016) package in RStudio to conduct power analyses for this study (R Core Team, 2018; RStudio Team, 2018). Monte Carlo simulation was used to determine an adequate sample size to detect a fixed time effect size (slope) of 0.2. The outcome is the difference score between the two change processes of interest. Thus, to detect a slope of 0.2 following one intervention with at least 90% power (specifically, 93.50%, CI = 91.79 to 94.95), we need 50 participants total and four assessment points per intervention.

question.value:
Main assessments
Cognitive strategies:
- The Cognitive Fusion Questionnaire (Gillanders et al., 2014) will be used to track changes in defusion. 
- The Thought Control Questionnaire – Reappraisal Subscale (Wells & Davies, 1994) will be used to track changes in the ability to rationally re-evaluate thought content. The original four-point Likert scale was changed to a seven-point scale (matching the CFQ scale) in order to facilitate combining variables for analyses.

Motivation strategies:
- The Engaged Living Scale – Valued Living Subscale (Trompetter et al., 2013) will be used to track changes in motivation and engagement. The original five-point Likert scale was changed to a seven-point scale (matching the CFQ scale) in order to facilitate combining variables for analyses.

Outcomes:
- The Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale–Brief (Burgess, Frost, & DiBartolo, 2016) will be used to track changes in perfectionism. 
- The Quality of Life Scale (Burckhardt & Anderson, 2003) will be used to track changes in subjective satisfaction and quality of life. 
- The Depression Anxiety and Stress Scale (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1996) will be used to track changes in anxiety and depression.
- The Self-Compassion Scale - Short Form (Raes, Pommier, Neff, & Van Gucht, 2011) will be used to track changes in self-compassion.



Session check in items (completed before each session)
Perfectionism items.
1.	I worried about not meeting expectations I set for myself.
2.	I did things (or avoided things) so I would not feel like a failure.
3.	I found it hard to do things less than perfectly.

Cognitive Variation. 
- Four face-valid items developed for the current study will be used to track idiosyncratic changes in cognitive variation. These include: 
1.	How much did you challenge the accuracy of your thoughts? 
2.	How much did you recognize that thoughts aren’t facts? 
3.	How much did the strategy you used for thoughts fit the situation? 
4.	How much did thoughts get in the way of what you wanted to do?

Motivational Variation. 
- The Engaged Living Scale – Valued Living Subscale (Trompetter et al., 2013) will be used to track changes in motivation and engagement.
- Four face-valid items developed for the current study will be used to track idiosyncratic changes in motivational variation. These include:
1.	How much did you consider reasons for choosing your actions (pros/cons, values)? 
2.	How much did you follow through on your chosen goals? 
3.	How much did the strategy you used for choosing your actions fit the situation? 
4.	How much did you do something because you felt like you should, not because it was important to you?


Items related to potential impacts of COVID-19:
Work and Social Adjustment Scale (Mundt et al., 2005) will be used to measure functional impairment related to COVID-19. Administered at baseline, mid-treatment, post-treatment, and follow-up.

COVID-19 check-in. To assess the specific impact of COVID-19 on study participation.
"We're curious how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected your participation in this study. Think about how changes in your life in the past month related to COVID-19 (e.g., increased worry, disruption to daily activities, social isolation) changed how you would have otherwise engaged in the study."

1.	The coronavirus/COVID-19 made it harder for me to fully participate in the study (due to distraction, distress, anxiety, loss of income, loss of childcare, etc.). Answers will be on a 7-point Likert scale from "not at all" to "extremely."

2.	How did the coronavirus/COVID-19 make it easier or harder for you to participate in the study? For example, you had more time to engage in the sessions or the topics no longer applied to you due to a change in your work situation. Open ended question.

We will take the mean of each of the the four face-valid CVT and MVT items and the three face-valid perfectionism items to create idiographic measures of cognitive variation, motivation variation, and perfectionism.

We will use multilevel models to investigate the effect of trainings on change processes (i.e., cognitive variation and motivational variation) and wellbeing over time (within-group effect). The two conceptual tests targeted in these analyses are (1) test of procedural specificity (e.g., does CVT only move cognitive variation?) and (2) test of process utility (e.g., does improvement in cognitive variation shift meaningful outcomes?). Participants will be specified in the model as a random factor to control for interclass correlations. Time will be specified as a fixed factor. Chi-square tests on the log-likelihood values will be used to compare linear, quadratic, and polynomial time variables in order of increasing complexity in order to find the best fitting model. The final model will be specified with restricted maximum likelihood (REML). The same steps will be repeated for each outcome variable of interest.

Predictors include: group and time.

Outcomes include: cognitive strategies, motivation strategies, quality of life, self-compassion, perfectionism, psychological distress, differences between cognitive and motivation strategies (within each module).

*Cognitive strategies, motivation strategies, and perfectionism will be measured using validated measures and face valid items created specifically for the study. Primary analyses will use the validate measures and secondary (exploratory) analyses will use the face valid items used during the intervention phase of the study.

q21.value: We will use p<.05 as the criteria for determine if results are significant

q22.value:
Awareness checks will include:
1- Removal of data from assessments that were completed at a rate faster than two seconds per item.
2- Removal of data from assessments that include 15 or more of the same answer repeated consecutively (longstring).
Both of these checks are conservative and should not exclude legitimate responses. Criteria were informed by careless responding research (Niessen, Meijer, Tendeiro (2016).

Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: We will follow the intent to treat method of including all available data, whether subjects drop out or fail to fully complete assessments.

Monte Carlo simulation was used to determine an adequate sample size to detect a fixed time effect size (slope) of 0.2. The outcome is the difference score between the two change processes of interest. Thus, to detect a slope of 0.2 following one intervention with at least 90% power (specifically, 93.50%, CI = 91.79 to 94.95), we need 50 participants total and four assessment points per intervention.
registration_responses.q21: We will use p<.05 as the criteria for determine if results are significant
registration_responses.q22:
Awareness checks will include:
1- Removal of data from assessments that were completed at a rate faster than two seconds per item.
2- Removal of data from assessments that include 15 or more of the same answer repeated consecutively (longstring).
Both of these checks are conservative and should not exclude legitimate responses. Criteria were informed by careless responding research (Niessen, Meijer, Tendeiro (2016).

Outliers will be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q23: We will follow the intent to treat method of including all available data, whether subjects drop out or fail to fully complete assessments.
registration_responses.q8.question:
The design is a randomized controlled crossover trial with two online trainings. We chose a crossover design because (1) participants serve as their own controls, minimizing the confounding influence of covariates, and (2) it allows investigation of each training, their combined effect, and potential order effects.

All components of the study will be delivered online, including gathering informed consent, completing the screening, intervention, and assessment at all time points. Individuals who are interested in participating in the study will provide informed consent and then be asked to complete a short screening. Those who qualify for the study will then complete a pre-intervention assessment battery and then be randomized to a starting intervention, either CVT or MVT. Participants will be prompted to complete two, 15–20 minute sessions each week. Combined, participants will complete eight sessions (four CVT and four MVT) over the course of four weeks. Assessment will be conducted at nine timepoints: baseline, twice during CVT and MVT interventions (four total), post CVT and MVT interventions (two total), and at three-month and six-month follow-up.

We will use multilevel models to investigate the effect of trainings on change processes (i.e., cognitive variation and motivational variation) and wellbeing over time (within-group effect).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited using online postings (e.g., Facebook, Reddit). To increase demographic diversity, we will primarily use “push out” strategies (i.e., target online users who are not primarily looking to participate in research) to advertise the study (Antoun, Zhang, Conrad, & Schober, 2016).

Inclusion criteria for the study include: (1) reliable Internet and smartphone access, (2) at least 18 years old, (3) score of ≥29 (one standard deviation above nonclinical mean) on the Concern Over Mistakes subscale on the Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (cut-off used in a previous telehealth treatment trial; Frost, Marten, Lahart, & Rosenblate, 1990; Rozental et al., 2017), and (4) fluency in English. Exclusion criteria include (1) self-reported suicidality and (2) concurrent psychotherapy.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Main assessments
Cognitive strategies:
- The Cognitive Fusion Questionnaire (Gillanders et al., 2014) will be used to track changes in defusion. 
- The Thought Control Questionnaire – Reappraisal Subscale (Wells & Davies, 1994) will be used to track changes in the ability to rationally re-evaluate thought content. The original four-point Likert scale was changed to a seven-point scale (matching the CFQ scale) in order to facilitate combining variables for analyses.

Motivation strategies:
- The Engaged Living Scale – Valued Living Subscale (Trompetter et al., 2013) will be used to track changes in motivation and engagement. The original five-point Likert scale was changed to a seven-point scale (matching the CFQ scale) in order to facilitate combining variables for analyses.

Outcomes:
- The Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale–Brief (Burgess, Frost, & DiBartolo, 2016) will be used to track changes in perfectionism. 
- The Quality of Life Scale (Burckhardt & Anderson, 2003) will be used to track changes in subjective satisfaction and quality of life. 
- The Depression Anxiety and Stress Scale (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1996) will be used to track changes in anxiety and depression.
- The Self-Compassion Scale - Short Form (Raes, Pommier, Neff, & Van Gucht, 2011) will be used to track changes in self-compassion.



Session check in items (completed before each session)
Perfectionism items.
1.	I worried about not meeting expectations I set for myself.
2.	I did things (or avoided things) so I would not feel like a failure.
3.	I found it hard to do things less than perfectly.

Cognitive Variation. 
- Four face-valid items developed for the current study will be used to track idiosyncratic changes in cognitive variation. These include: 
1.	How much did you challenge the accuracy of your thoughts? 
2.	How much did you recognize that thoughts aren’t facts? 
3.	How much did the strategy you used for thoughts fit the situation? 
4.	How much did thoughts get in the way of what you wanted to do?

Motivational Variation. 
- The Engaged Living Scale – Valued Living Subscale (Trompetter et al., 2013) will be used to track changes in motivation and engagement.
- Four face-valid items developed for the current study will be used to track idiosyncratic changes in motivational variation. These include:
1.	How much did you consider reasons for choosing your actions (pros/cons, values)? 
2.	How much did you follow through on your chosen goals? 
3.	How much did the strategy you used for choosing your actions fit the situation? 
4.	How much did you do something because you felt like you should, not because it was important to you?


Items related to potential impacts of COVID-19:
Work and Social Adjustment Scale (Mundt et al., 2005) will be used to measure functional impairment related to COVID-19. Administered at baseline, mid-treatment, post-treatment, and follow-up.

COVID-19 check-in. To assess the specific impact of COVID-19 on study participation.
"We're curious how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected your participation in this study. Think about how changes in your life in the past month related to COVID-19 (e.g., increased worry, disruption to daily activities, social isolation) changed how you would have otherwise engaged in the study."

1.	The coronavirus/COVID-19 made it harder for me to fully participate in the study (due to distraction, distress, anxiety, loss of income, loss of childcare, etc.). Answers will be on a 7-point Likert scale from "not at all" to "extremely."

2.	How did the coronavirus/COVID-19 make it easier or harder for you to participate in the study? For example, you had more time to engage in the sessions or the topics no longer applied to you due to a change in your work situation. Open ended question.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will take the mean of each of the the four face-valid CVT and MVT items and the three face-valid perfectionism items to create idiographic measures of cognitive variation, motivation variation, and perfectionism.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use multilevel models to investigate the effect of trainings on change processes (i.e., cognitive variation and motivational variation) and wellbeing over time (within-group effect). The two conceptual tests targeted in these analyses are (1) test of procedural specificity (e.g., does CVT only move cognitive variation?) and (2) test of process utility (e.g., does improvement in cognitive variation shift meaningful outcomes?). Participants will be specified in the model as a random factor to control for interclass correlations. Time will be specified as a fixed factor. Chi-square tests on the log-likelihood values will be used to compare linear, quadratic, and polynomial time variables in order of increasing complexity in order to find the best fitting model. The final model will be specified with restricted maximum likelihood (REML). The same steps will be repeated for each outcome variable of interest.

Predictors include: group and time.

Outcomes include: cognitive strategies, motivation strategies, quality of life, self-compassion, perfectionism, psychological distress, differences between cognitive and motivation strategies (within each module).

*Cognitive strategies, motivation strategies, and perfectionism will be measured using validated measures and face valid items created specifically for the study. Primary analyses will use the validate measures and secondary (exploratory) analyses will use the face valid items used during the intervention phase of the study.

attributes.title: Can grape products affect appetitive sensations and food intake? - A systematic review of randomized clinical trials

q1.value: Can grape products affect appetitive sensations and food intake?  A systematic review of randomized clinical trials

q2.value: Olivia Gonçalves Leão Coelho, Priscila Vaz de Melo Ribeiro, Rita de Cássia Gonçalves Alfenas

q3.value: Food intake control is essential to prevent weight gain. Grape components contain anti‐obesity agents, which present satiating effects that may improve body composition. Some polyphenols seem to have the potential to modulate neuropeptides, increasing satiety and reducing food intake. However, these effects in humans are not fully comprehended as well as the mechanisms involved. Therefore, this study aims to critically analyze human randomized clinical trials in which the effects of grapes or of grape products on appetite, satiety, and food intake were investigated, and to elucidate the possible mechanisms involved.

q4.value: If grape products modulate appetite, they will increase satiety and reduce food intake.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
1) Types of study: we will include human randomized clinical trial  that used a concurrent control group; adopted grapes and/or grape products as intervention; provided the primary outcomes baseline and endpoint values; grapes and/or grape products were not part of any preparation provided; grape phenolic compounds as multi-component supplement were not provided. We will not include studies in vitro, with animals, with smokers, pregnant or lactating women, as well as comments, reviews, protocols, letters, case reports, transversal studies, abstracts, and unpublished articles. In order to minimize publication bias the search will not be restricted by language or date of publication.
2) Types or participants: adults with normal body weight or with overweight, with no associated comorbidities 
3) Types of intervention:  consumption of grape or a derived product, consumed alone, not as part of a preparation or a component of dietary supplement.
4) Types of outcomes measures:
- Primary outcomes: appetite, satiety, and food intake 
- Secondary outcomes: meal palatability, tolerance, acceptance, macronutrient composition, and gut hormones.

q9.value: Not applicable as this is a systematic review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will search PubMed, Scopus, and Cochrane Library database for RCTs designed to assess the effects of grapes and/or grape products on appetite, satiety and food intake in humans. The keywords were chosen from the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and Descriptors in Health Sciences (DeHS) using the following search strategy: (“grape”) AND (“appetite”) OR (“food intake”) OR (“satiety”). A reverse hand-search will also be performed to identify relevant articles cited in all selected studies.
Not applicable.

Primary outcomes: Appetitive sensation, satiety, and food intake or energy intake.
Secondary outcomes: Meal palatability, tolerance, acceptance, macronutrient composition, and gut hormones.
Not applicable

We will assess the risk of bias using the Cochrane Collaboration method. The studies will be analyzed on three levels of bias: high risk, low risk, and unclear (if the information provided is not sufficient to make a clear judgment). We will consider the following biases: random sequence generation and allocation concealment (selection bias), blinding of participants and staff (performance bias), blinding of results evaluation (detection bias), selective reporting (notification bias), and incomplete outcome data (attrition bias). Different opinions between the authors will be settled by consensus.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
a) We are also going to explore how condition (amplification vs. control) and voice type (promotive vs. prohibitive) affect idea quality. Idea quality will be measured using the following six items: 
The idea was based on the best available information. 
The idea was made based on valid assumptions. 
The idea helps InsureCo achieve its objectives. 
The idea makes sense in light of this sales team's current situation 
The idea is consistent with InsureCo's current strategy. 
The idea contributes to the overall effectiveness of InsureCo. 

We will combine all items as long as alpha is greater than .7; otherwise, we will drop the lowest-loading items until we have a subset of items with alpha is greater than .7.

c) We will explore whether agency mediates the relationship between condition and amplifier status.
 We will explore whether agency and communality mediate the relationships between condition and contributor status. 
d) Several of the stimuli are sampled from a larger set (e.g., we use three different ideas). We do this for generalizability, and we are not interested in modeling the variance due to stimuli—in other words, we will collapse across stimuli. 
e) Participants will rate the third person in the meeting on the same status, communality, and agency measures, but this person’s actions are identical across conditions, and we are not interested in participant ratings of this person. The items are included to reduce suspicion around the purpose of the study

sample.value: N=800 participants from MTurk. Due to the data collection process on Amazon's Mechanical Turk, it is possible that we will collect slightly more than 800; then with exclusions (see previous section) we will have a slightly smaller sample.

analyses.value: We will perform a MANOVA to examine the effect of amplification and voice type on each of our three measures (status, agency, and communality) for each of the two key people. We will use an interaction term to explore the relationship between amplification and voice type on the dependent measures

outliers.value:
We will delete data from any duplicate IP addresses and any duplicate worker IDs. 
We ask two comprehension check questions (“You were asked to imagine you were part of what company?” and “You are meeting with the sales team because:”) and will eliminate participants who answer one or both questions incorrectly (i.e., do not select “InsureCo” and “performance hasn’t been very good lately.”)
Participants are asked to “In your own words, write the idea that [ER] suggested in this meeting” and we will exclude participants who write irrelevant responses.

dependent.value:
Participants will rate two different key people on the following three DVs: status, agency, and communality. For each index, we will combine all items as long as alpha > .7; otherwise, we will drop the lowest-loading items until we have a subset of items with alpha > .7

Status will be measured using the following five items:
Status in the group
Influence in the group 
Admired by group
Respected by group
Prestige

Agency will be measured using the following six items:
Competent
Capable 
Intelligent 
Efficient
Independent 
Confident

Communality will be measured using the following six items:
Helpful to others 
Trustworthy
Supportive
Friendly
Warm
Sincere

conditions.value: We will use a 2 (condition: amplification vs. control) by 2 (voice type: promotive vs. prohibitive) design.

hypothesis.value:
When individuals contribute an idea (aka contributors) and someone amplifies (aka amplifiers), our previous research shows that the status of contributors and amplifiers increases. In this study, we ask, does the way a contributor frames the idea (i.e., prohibitively or promotively) matter for obtaining these effects? 

1.	We predict a main effect of amplification increasing the status of the amplifier relative to control and that communality is a mediator (replication of our previous finding).
2.	We will explore whether amplification differentially affects the status of the amplifier dependent on the framing of the idea (i.e., the interaction is exploratory—we have no a priori prediction about whether amplifying a promotive vs. prohibitive voice will have a differential increase on the amplifier’s status relative to not amplifying the idea).
3.	We predict the contributor’s status to be higher when the contributor uses promotive voice rather than prohibitive voice. 
4.	We will explore whether amplification differentially affects the status of the contributor dependent on framing of the idea (i.e., the interaction is exploratory—we have no a priori prediction about whether amplifying promotive vs. prohibitive voice will have a differential increase on the contributor’s status relative to not amplifying the idea). 
5.	We also predict a main effect of amplification increasing the status of the contributor) (unless the interaction overpowers it).
We will explore how voice type (i.e., promotive or prohibitive) affect the relationships between amplification and the status of both the amplifier and the person contributing. We will also explore how amplification of promotive and prohibitive voice affects ratings of voice quality.

attributes.title: Psychological, Behavioral, and Social Response to the 2020 Coronavirus Pandemic

q1.value: Acute Personality Trait Change in Response to the Coronavirus Pandemic

q2.value: Angelina Sutin, Antonio Terracciano, Martina Luchetti, Damaris Aschwanden, Jason Strickhouser, Ji Hyun Lee, Amanda A. Sesker

q3.value:
The world is currently facing a pandemic over the novel coronavirus (SARS-Cov-19) that causes the respiratory disease COVID-19. As of March 17, 2020, there is widespread concern over the extent of the spread of the disease and its potential impact on communities and on the economy. The entire country of Italy is in quarantine, and the virus is rapidly spreading across France and Spain. Schools, businesses, and entertainment are closed across the United States. There is a lot of uncertainty about how far the disease has spread, the strength of the healthcare infrastructure to treat patients if the numbers keep going up, and how long extreme measures will last before the outbreak is contained.

The present study follows-up on a survey that was fielded between January 31, 2020 and February 10, 2020. During this time, coronavirus spread rapidly through China but had not spread yet in Europe or North America. This already collected data will thus serve as the pretest. On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization labeled the coronavirus a pandemic, and there has been rapid spread around the world and increasingly strict measures taken to stop its spread. We will conduct another survey on the participants who completed the baseline pretest assessment. The current survey re-tests these original participants during the middle of March 2020. This new data collection will serve as the posttest. The overall purpose of this project is to test whether there are acute personality changes in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

q4.value:
Primary hypothesis: We hypothesize that Neuroticism will increase, particularly the facets of anxiety and emotional volatility, between pretest and posttest.

Secondary hypothesis: We hypothesize that Conscientiousness, particularly the facet of responsibility/dutifulness, will increase between pre-test and post-test. We do not make hypotheses for how the other three traits might change.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within subjects design with two repeated measures of personality traits (pre- and post- coronavirus spread)

q9.value: Survey blocks will be randomized. After reporting demographic information, participants will first get either the block with the personality measure or the block with questions about their response to the coronavirus pandemic. All participants will complete all blocks. Qualtrics will randomize the order upon starting the survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: This project uses both existing data that has not yet been analyzed and data that are about to be collected. The pretest data were collected between January 31, 2020 and February 10, 2020 and have not yet been analyzed. We will collect new data for posttest.

question.value:
Pretest. The original data collection was stratified to be 50% male/female, 20% African American, with equal numbers (n=500) of participants for each of seven age bands: 18-19, 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, and 70 and older. Participants had to be located in the United States to participate. We contracted with Dynata (https://www.dynata.com/) for participant recruitment. Dynata samples through their proprietary participant panels. Participants were compensated through Dynata. During data collection, participants aged 30-59 were inadvertently oversampled and the 18-19 year olds under-sampled. The 18-19 age band ultimately did get fully sampled in the pretest. As such, 30-59 year olds were oversampled relative to the other age bands. In addition, the 60-69 and 70 and older age bands were slightly under-sampled compared to the target recruitment.

Posttest. The new data collection will be restricted to participants who completed the pretest. All participants will be recontacted by Dynata to complete another survey. Dynata estimates a 40-60% retention rate. Participants periodically leave their proprietary panels. Dynata no longer contacts participants once they leave the panel. We do not have any personally-identifiable information on the participants and cannot contact participants directly.

q13.value: We expect that at least 40% of the original target of 3,500 participants (N=1,400) will complete the survey.

q14.value: The sample size is based on the previous data collection (pretest).

q15.value: The population is a fixed cohort. We will try to test as many participants as possible from this fixed cohort.

question.value:
At pretest, personality traits were measured with the Big Five Inventory-2. The BFI measures the five broad domains of personality and three more specific facets for each trait. In addition, the responsibility facet from Roberts' 2005 measure of Conscientiousness and the dutifulness facet from the NEO-PI-3 were administered at pretest. The same measures will be administered at posttest.

Covariates are self-reported age, gender, race, and education.

Other variables, such as loneliness, depressed affect, and response to the coronavirus are also measured. See pretest survey and posttest survey for all measures administered.

All personality measures will be scored as indicated by the scoring system for the scales (i.e., items will be reverse scored when necessary in the direction of the trait label and the mean taken across items).

A repeated-measures ANOVA will be used to test change in personality between pre- and post-test. In a second model, we will also include sociodemographic variables (age, gender, race/ethnicity, education). We will also conduct exploratory analyses to test whether changes in personality are moderated by age or gender.

q22.value: Participants who show evidence of careless responding (e.g., demographics do not match across the two surveys) or straight-lining (i.e., giving the same answer across the personality inventory) will be excluded.

q23.value: Participants with missing data on personality (>20% of personality items) will be excluded from the analyses.

q24.value: We will test whether changes in personality are moderated by age or gender.

This new data collection will serve as the posttest. The overall purpose of this project is to test whether there are acute personality changes in response to the coronavirus epidemic.
registration_responses.q4:
Primary hypothesis: We hypothesize that Neuroticism will increase, particularly the facets of anxiety and emotional volatility, between pretest and posttest.

Secondary hypothesis: We hypothesize that Conscientiousness, particularly the facet of responsibility/dutifulness, will increase between pre-test and post-test. We do not make hypotheses for how the other three traits might change.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: Survey blocks will be randomized. After reporting demographic information, participants will first get either the block with the personality measure or the block with questions about their response to the coronavirus pandemic. All participants will complete all blocks. Qualtrics will randomize the order upon starting the survey.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: This project uses both existing data that has not yet been analyzed and data that are about to be collected. The pretest data were collected between January 31, 2020 and February 10, 2020 and have not yet been analyzed. We will collect new data for posttest.
registration_responses.q13: We expect that at least 40% of the original target of 3,500 participants (N=1,400) will complete the survey.
registration_responses.q14: The sample size is based on the previous data collection (pretest).
registration_responses.q15: The population is a fixed cohort. We will try to test as many participants as possible from this fixed cohort.
registration_responses.q22: Participants who show evidence of careless responding (e.g., demographics do not match across the two surveys) or straight-lining (i.e., giving the same answer across the personality inventory) will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Participants with missing data on personality (>20% of personality items) will be excluded from the analyses.
registration_responses.q24: We will test whether changes in personality are moderated by age or gender.
registration_responses.q8.question: Within subjects design with two repeated measures of personality traits (pre- and post- coronavirus spread)
registration_responses.q12.question:
Pretest. The original data collection was stratified to be 50% male/female, 20% African American, with equal numbers (n=500) of participants for each of seven age bands: 18-19, 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, and 70 and older. Participants had to be located in the United States to participate. We contracted with Dynata (https://www.dynata.com/) for participant recruitment. Dynata samples through their proprietary participant panels. Participants were compensated through Dynata. During data collection, participants aged 30-59 were inadvertently oversampled and the 18-19 year olds under-sampled. The 18-19 age band ultimately did get fully sampled in the pretest. As such, 30-59 year olds were oversampled relative to the other age bands. In addition, the 60-69 and 70 and older age bands were slightly under-sampled compared to the target recruitment.

Posttest. The new data collection will be restricted to participants who completed the pretest. All participants will be recontacted by Dynata to complete another survey. Dynata estimates a 40-60% retention rate. Participants periodically leave their proprietary panels. Dynata no longer contacts participants once they leave the panel. We do not have any personally-identifiable information on the participants and cannot contact participants directly.
registration_responses.q17.question:
At pretest, personality traits were measured with the Big Five Inventory-2. The BFI measures the five broad domains of personality and three more specific facets for each trait. In addition, the responsibility facet from Roberts' 2005 measure of Conscientiousness and the dutifulness facet from the NEO-PI-3 were administered at pretest. The same measures will be administered at posttest.

Covariates are self-reported age, gender, race, and education.

Other variables, such as loneliness, depressed affect, and response to the coronavirus are also measured. See pretest survey and posttest survey for all measures administered.
registration_responses.q18.question: All personality measures will be scored as indicated by the scoring system for the scales (i.e., items will be reverse scored when necessary in the direction of the trait label and the mean taken across items).
registration_responses.q19.question: A repeated-measures ANOVA will be used to test change in personality between pre- and post-test. In a second model, we will also include sociodemographic variables (age, gender, race/ethnicity, education). We will also conduct exploratory analyses to test whether changes in personality are moderated by age or gender.
